awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding Indigenous Contributions to Arctic Biodiversity Conservation Efforts
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation project examines how Indigenous researchers, science professionals, and local communities shape the discussions around conservation of lands and species across the Arctic. Arctic Peoples have been engaged in biodiversity conservation efforts though many challenges remain to meaningful participation. This research involves four approaches that examine (1) the contributions of Indigenous communities to Arctic biodiversity research in data collection, planning, implementation, evaluation, and reporting; (2) the ways in which Indigenous Knowledge and science partner to provide data for use in conservation planning; (3) the perceptions of the barriers to diverse participation in conservation efforts, and; (4) the facilitation of participatory processes of current Arctic conservation projects and initiatives. This research studies the human dimensions of conservation, improving scientific methodologies by identifying tools and approaches for meaningfully engaging Indigenous Peoples and other stakeholders, documenting diverse approaches to addressing biodiversity efforts, improving the management and conservation of Arctic landscapes, and partnering Indigenous knowledge and science for conservation science. While this research focuses on the Arctic, the findings will have application for better understanding the intersection of conservation efforts and participatory designs across the world. 

This research identifies thirty proposed study locations for intensive field study as information on these research topics is often limited, only partially recorded, recorded in a language other than English, or captured in the living memories of professionals and community members engaged in conservation efforts. Data collection and analyses for the four studies include, (1) gathering published literature on Arctic biodiversity research for content analysis (n=100), (2) case study development, comparative case study analysis, and focused comparison of conservation projects engaged in knowledge co-production (n=10), (3) 30-minute semi-structured interviews of Indigenous and conservation professionals analyzed via transcription, qualitative data analysis software, and thematic coding (n=50), and (4) comparative case study analysis of Indigenous use of, and engagement in, Arctic protected areas via process tracing, focused comparison, content analysis, and principal component analysis (n=35). Results from this research will clarify how Indigenous participation contributes to conservation science and goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: School of Enviromental and Forest Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Victoria Qutuuq Buschman has completed her dissertation research "Understanding Indigenous Contributions to Arctic Biodiversity Conservation Efforts" which was supported in part through this dissertation improvement grant. During her funding period, she spent two years as a visiting researcher at the Greenland Institute of Natural Resources while pursuing her research on Arctic conservation in circumpolar Indigenous homelands. Victoria was particularly interested in Indigenous knowledge of biodiversity, ecosystems, and environmental dynamics, Indigenous-led conceptions of conservation planning and practice, and co-productive approaches. Beyond more conventional natural science research on Arctic biodiversity and protected areas, Victoria travelled to meet with Indigenous organizations and representatives, community members, and researchers, managers, and practitioners in the field across the circumpolar north.  

While the global coronavirus pandemic inhibited much travel throughout Indigenous homelands in the Arctic during the later half of the granting period, she was still able to visit physically with Indigenous organizations and representatives and Arctic researchers to discuss this work in Greenland, Norway, Iceland, Scotland, and Switzerland. This research was presented on at Arctic conferences, research institutions, educational institutions, and organizations nineteen times over the course of the granting period. Results from this research have also been used in her research and policy advising activities at the International Arctic Science Committee, the Conservation of Arctic Flora and Fauna (CAFF) biodiversity working group of the Arctic Council, and various bodies of the United Nations. Notably, results and guidance from this research project were also shared and discussed at both the science sessions and Indigenous closed-door sessions of the UNFCCC COP26.

Victoria?s research at the University of Washington and the Greenland Institute of Natural Resources builds on her previous dissertation research at CAFF to form the basis of her dissertation. This dissertation was formally completed in the summer of 2021 and is a unique contribution to both conservation research and practice in Arctic Indigenous homelands. Three manuscripts from this NSF supported research are currently in review for publication in academic journals. Her full dissertation is published through the University of Washington, and one dissertation chapter is additionally available as a CAFF technical report entitled "Arctic Wetlands and Indigenous Peoples Study: An assessment of Indigenous engagement in wetland protected areas."

As a direct result of this dissertation improvement grant, Victoria currently serves as the first Inuk Dr. of Conservation Biology in the world, is the only Dr. of Conservation Biology sitting in Greenland, and has transitioned to a PostDoc position at the International Arctic Research Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. She is carrying forward the research conducted through this grant award to new projects and publications.

 


Last Modified: 05/11/2022
Modified by: Victoria R Buschman
